title: 106_s2941
content: The Act titled "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2000" requires additional monthly and quarterly disclosure reports. The Act "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2000" mandates monthly and quarterly disclosure reports for principal campaign committees, with specific deadlines for filing. The Act "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2000" requires timely filing of quarterly reports by the treasurer and national committees of political parties, with specific deadlines outlined. Amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 ensure compliance with reporting requirements. The Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports instead of quarterly reports. Additionally, Section 309 of the Act is amended to replace "calendar quarter" with "month". SEC. 102. REPORTING BY NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national and congressional political committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period. Political committees must itemize receipts or disbursements exceeding $200 from any person in the same manner as required in subsection (b). Reports required to be filed under this subsection shall be filed for the same time periods required for political committees under subsection (a). SEC. 103 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require the Commission to make reports available online within 24 hours. SEC. 104 addresses public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make available for public inspection a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including acceptance/rejection, rates, air date/time, class of time, candidate's name and office, election or issue referenced, and candidate's name for requests made by or on behalf of a candidate. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including details like the name of the person purchasing the time, contact information, and a list of key executives involved. This information must be kept in a political file for at least 2 years. SEC. 201 imposes limits on soft money of national political party committees under Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Limits are imposed on donations, gifts, or transfers of funds to political party committees, with a maximum aggregate amount of $60,000 per person per calendar year. Additionally, individuals are restricted from making disbursements exceeding $60,000 in a calendar year. Amount limits are adjusted annually based on the price index. The amount limits for donations to political party committees are adjusted annually based on the price index, with the base period set at calendar year 2000. The increased amounts will be effective for each calendar year. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Expedited Review: Members of Congress, candidates, political party committees, or affected individuals can challenge the constitutionality of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. Appeals on injunctions or final decisions from this court can be directly reviewed by the Supreme Court. The jurisdictional statement must be filed within 30 days of the order. The District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court must expedite the disposition of cases under subsection (a). Enforcement of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act is stayed until the Supreme Court's final decision. This section applies to actions filed within 30 days under subsection (a). Actions under subsection (a) must be filed within 30 days of this Act's effective date. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including raising individual and political committee contribution limits to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively. Multicandidate limits also increased to $7,500. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits, with individual and political committee limits raised to $7,500 and $30,000 respectively. Indexing provisions are also adjusted for calendar years after 2000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits, with individual and political committee limits raised to $7,500 and $30,000 respectively. The amendments made by this section shall apply to calendar years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 301 prohibits the solicitation of political party soft money in federal buildings. Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to define "contribution" in connection with elections for Federal office or political committees. Section 602(a)(4) is also amended to include prohibition of donations. The definition of "contribution" in connection with elections for Federal office or political committees is amended to include prohibition of donations. SEC. 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust penalty amounts for inflation based on the price index determined under section 315(c) for calendar years after 2000. This adjustment does not apply to amounts under subsection (d) other than the $25,000 amount.
